sentence.text: The patient was born at 37 weeks gestation to a 24-year-old G1 P0-1 mother and 26-year-old father.
The pregnancy was uncomplicated until 8 months when sonographic measurements of fetal limb length revealed a short-limbed dwarfing condition and polyhydramnios.
The possibility that this could represent campomelic dysplasia was suggested.
Genetic amniocentesis revealed a normal male karyotype.
Birth weight was 2.5 kg (10th centile), birth length was 38 cm (<3rd centile), and head circumference was 35 cm (50th centile).
Physical exam revealed an obvious dwarfing condition associated with rhizomelic shortening of the limbs, small chest circumference, unusual hair, and hypospadias.
Brachydactyly with trident appearance of the hands was noted.
Feet were small.
Macrocephaly was present with prominent scalp veins.
The patient remained in the hospital for 10 days.
The patient had pulmonary hypoplasia due to a small chest circumference and required oxygen for the first 18 months of life.
He developed obstructive airway disease and asthma.
At the age of 4 months, he was noted to have anemia which required two transfusions.
He has taken iron supplementation since 13 months of age and significant anemia has not recurred.
An echocardiogram demonstrated a bicuspid aortic valve and very small apical ventricular septal defects which closed spontaneously.
Bilateral inguinal hernias, hypospadias, and chordee were surgically repaired.
The patient has had frequent urinary tract infections although renal ultrasounds were normal.
He has been followed by gastroenterology for gastroesophageal reflux and constipation.
The patient has complained of knee, hip, back, and neck pain, prompting evaluation in a neuromuscular clinic.
At 2½ years, a head MRI noted dilatation of the lateral and third ventricles due to obstruction of outflow tracts of the 4th ventricle.
An extremely small foramen magnum with low cerebellar tonsils was noted.
A ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed and the hydrocephalus has been stable.
At 9 years of age, a follow-up MRI identified a Chiari I malformation which required repair.
The patient has hyperopia first diagnosed between 1 and 2 years of age.
Strabismus was surgically repaired at 13 months.
He has had a normal audiology evaluation.
He has no history of recurrent ear infections.
He was found to have a moderate quantitative T-cell deficiency not requiring intervention or therapy.
He has had fine, scant scalp hair since birth and minimal body hair.
Fingernails are thin and brittle, and fingernails and toenails are hypoplastic.
Dental eruption did not occur until 12–20 months.

At 14 years of age, the patient remains short in stature with a height of 88.7 cm (9 SD below the mean), relative macrocephaly, a slightly narrow chest, slight lumbar lordosis, rhizomelic shortening, and decreased extension of the elbows (Fig. 1).
His hair remains sparse.
He has brachydactyly of the hands and feet (Fig. 2).
Radiographic studies performed at one day of life showed short, thick tubular bones with flared metaphyses and short metacarpals and phalanges.
Ribs were short.
There were narrowed sciatic notches and acetabular roofs were mildly flattened with squaring of the iliac wings.
The diagnosis of “achondroplasia without narrowed interpedicular distance” was suggested.
Radiographs at 6 months showed short, dumbbell-shaped femurs, tibiae and humerii, splaying of the metaphyses and epiphyses, and irregular calcifications of the epiphyses.
Platyspondyly and coronal clefting, widening of the ribs, a trefoil-shaped pelvis, and a hypoplastic sciatic notch were present.
The diagnoses of Kniest dysplasia and the Glasgow variant of thanatophoric dysplasia were suggested at this time.

Radiographs at 8 years of age revealed shortening and pronounced bowing of the femurs, metaphyseal flaring, tibial widening and proximal flaring and short, and wide bones in the hands and feet (Fig. 3).
There were no metaphyseal irregularities or cystic lesions in the knees, ankles, long bones, or hands.
Epiphyses of the femurs, knees, and ankles did not appear round, enlarged, or globular in appearance.

None of the rarer skeletal findings seen in CHH were noted, such as increased femoral ossification, short, wide iliac wings, fibulae longer than tibiae, or decreased pronation or supination of the elbows.
Gross motor milestones were initially delayed due to macrocephaly.
The patient rolled over at 16 months, sat up at 16 months, and began walking at 35 months.
He spoke his first words at 2½ years.
He has not had formal IQ testing, but he performs well in regular classes at school, and there have been no concerns about cognitive delay.
The patient is the first of two children born to his parents.
His parents and sister are of normal stature, and there is no family history of other individuals with short stature or known skeletal dysplasias.
The mother is of German, Scottish, English, and Native American descent.
The father is of German, Norwegian, Scottish, and French Basque descent.
Consanguinity is denied.
